reg.title: Physical Therapists Regulation
reg.amsincluded: [includes amendments up to B.C. Reg. 9/2006, January 30, 2006]

definition.def: means the treatment of the human body by physical or mechanical means, by manipulation, massage, exercise, the application of bandages, hydrotherapy, and medical electricity, for the therapeutic purpose of maintaining or restoring function that has been impaired by injury or disease.

subsection.subsectiontext: Physical therapy is designated as a health profession.
The "College of Physical Therapists of British Columbia" is the name of the college established under section 15 (1) of the Health Professions Act for physical therapy.

section.sectiontext: No person other than a registrant may use the title "physical therapist", "registered physical therapist", "physiotherapist", "registered physiotherapist", "remedial gymnast" or "registered remedial gymnast".
A registrant may practise physical therapy.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to section 14 of the Health Professions Act, no person other than a registrant may practise physical therapy.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a person employed by and on the premises of a hospital which has been designated by the minister and who is acting under the direction of a medical practitioner.

section.sectiontext: No registrant may prescribe or administer drugs or anaesthetics, or treat a recent fracture of a bone, except under the direction of a medical practitioner.
The college is designated for the purposes of section 16 (2) (f) of the Health Professions Act.
Part 4 of the Health Professions Act applies to physical therapy.
